Name: Tomato Leaf Mold
Description: Tomato leaf mold is a fungal disease that affects the foliage of tomato plants. It is caused by the pathogen Passalora fulva and is characterized by yellowing of the upper surface of the leaves, followed by the development of grayish-brown fuzzy growth on the undersides of the leaves. The disease can cause defoliation, reduced yield, and lower fruit quality.

Treatments.Crop rotation: Plant tomatoes in a different location each year to reduce the build-up of fungal spores in the soil.

Treatments.Pruning: Remove infected leaves as soon as you see symptoms to prevent the disease from spreading to other parts of the plant.

Treatments.Cultural practices: Ensure adequate air circulation around plants by spacing them appropriately, watering at the base of plants instead of from overhead, and avoiding excessive nitrogen fertilizer application.

Treatments.Disease-resistant varieties: Choose tomato varieties that are resistant to early blight to reduce the likelihood of infection.

Products.Chlorothalonil: Such as Bravo, can be effective in controlling early blight. These products can be applied preventively or at the first sign of disease.

Products.Azoxystrobin or Pyraclostrobin: These are systemic fungicides that can be used as a preventive measure or as a curative treatment when the disease is still in the early stages.

Products.Myclobutanil: A contact fungicide that is effective against many fungal diseases, including common rust.
